transcript.title: Doorstop Interview, Parliament House, Canberra
transcript.subjects: New counter-terrorism measures for a safer Australia.
transcript.content:
PRIME MINISTER:

No one who has been following the internet footage of these Australian born and bred people whoâve gone to Syria and Iraq to engage in terrorist activities couldnât be concerned. Youâve got people born in Australia, educated in Australia, going overseas and exaltedly holding up the severed heads of surrendering members of the Iraqi security forces, obviously, these are people who we wouldnât want to allow back into our country unsupervised. There are up to 150 Australians whoâve gone to Syria and Iraq to engage in terrorist activities and we need these stronger powers to keep our community safe.

QUESTION:

Prime Minister, how is storing Australiansâ web browsing history for purposes of general foreign fighting not a gross invasion of their privacy?

PRIME MINISTER:

Weâre not asking for anything that isnât already being done. This idea that we are asking the telecommunications providers to store material that isnât already kept and stored is just wrong, but as technology changes itâs quite likely that some of the material thatâs always been there will no longer be there and thatâs what we are exploring with the telecommunications providers. Thatâs what we want to legislate for to ensure that the material that we currently have which all the experts say is essential for crime fighting, which is essential for counter-terrorism work continues to be kept.

QUESTION:

So you will be keeping the history of peopleâs search engines? You will be keeping that?

PRIME MINISTER:

Well, we are not seeking content, we are seeking metadata. What you generate is content, what the service providers generate is metadata. We do think the metadata should be kept because all of the best security advice is that without this, counter-terrorism work becomes very difficult, crime fighting work becomes very difficult. But I stress, weâre not asking for new information, weâre simply asking the telecommunications providers to continue to keep information that they currently do.

[ends]
